title: Camp CycleYouth
description: MTB summer camp for ages 12-18, June 8-16.  All ability levels from Beginner to Expert are eat one camp; rides will split as needed. The Expert rides are set up more as a training camp where riders will do a lot of riding and training during the week, this is also open to Sport level riders who should be racing Ex. Attendees prefer this format rather than our previous format of classroom heavy learning. The fitness gains from this week of training will carry you to new levels. If you are racing the Beginner (Base) class then you likely will not have the fitness/endurance/speed that theExpert racers have, so will enjoy the targeted rides. Expert (cat 1) rides are typically 2-3 hours per day with the 7-day total being around 14-16 hours. This is a training camp, so expect a little suffering and sore legs. Participants should be highly motivated and ready to go each day. This will be more boot-camp than previous camps. The Beginner/Sport Camp is open to anyone with the ability and motivation to ride 6 consecutive days at 1.5-2 hours per, with a long ride extending past 3 hours possibly. These are camps put on by CycleYouth staff, but are open to any racer or mtb\'er on any team able to ride with the group. Most Sport/Ex campers are very fast Sport level racers. over age 16. Rides will range from 2 to 3 hours long, and some days will have two-a-dayers where we ride in the morning and also the afternoon. On the long days we will offer shorter options for any not feeling up to the task, and may opt for a longer ride depending on the group, or may join the shorter rides.  A few rides will be combined. The area\'s Forest are a beautiful riding location nestled in the Blue ridge mountains. The area is hilly and mountainous, so we will be riding rolling terrain one day and mountainous the next. Early morning activities include strength and conditioning training and other off-bike training related interest. The Beginner/Sport camp includes racers of this ability level, and some non-racers who have the fitness and endurance to complete the rides with the group. This is not a camp for those interested in beginning mountain bike, however. The fitness needed to complete the rides can only come from riding a bike (not running, swimming, or other sports). Generally those who do well are riders who currently ride 3-4 days per week for 1-2 hours on each ride. One-day-a-week riders will not be able to keep up with the group. General fitness, proficiencies in other sports, motivation and determination are of no help for a non-cyclist or a cyclist that rarely rides. The camps intent is to help cyclist jump to the next level both in fitness and in skills. Many other areas of discussion will be covered to help create a well-rounded cyclist. Skills are hands on at the cabin or on the trails while instruction is a laid-back conversation style. For those interested we will offer a more structured discussion on training. We will skip the science and go directly to what matters in training. We will cover skills as in the past but more emphasis will be on training. We will discuss proper bike care and go over basic bike maintain and repair during optional instruction time. Riders will learn the basics of the training method and begin to understand the intricacies of race preparation, execution, nutrition and how training works. Campers will enjoy the good life with excellent trails and rides led by local residents and other camp staff. This camp was formerly part of the USA Cycling camp system. This camp will be the same successful format developed for that camp, just with more appropriate goals. This camp can still serve as a qualifier for the USAC camp. Food and lodging included. Campers only need gear and possibly some bedding. Early arrival, and transportation from Atlanta can be arranged. Airport pickup can also be arranged from Greenville/Spartanberg or Asheville Int.
course: Rolling and mountainous. rugged terrain. Lots of climbing with repetitive climbs of 5 - 10 minutes, and a few days including 40+ minute climbs.
registration: You may register through usacycling, or pay via PayPal (contact us through www.cycleyouth.com), or mail a check.  The camp will fill up fast this year as we have fewer spots available.  Cost is $650 for the week.
directions: The camp is located in Cedar Mountain, NC which is just over the State line North of SC and North of Greenville, SC.  We are 20 minutes from Brevard, NC, and 20 from Hendersonville, NC.

title: Pisgah Omnium
course:
OMNIUM  All 3 races  -- Time Trial, Crit & Road Race to qualify
Stage 1  Etowah Time Trial  Friday, July 5th, 2013
Stage 2: Brevard Criterium  Saturday, July 6th, 2013
Stage 3: Hendersonville Road Race  Sunday, July 7th, 2013
registration:
Online Registration closes at midnight EST on July 3rd, 2013. Must pre-register for the omnium in order to qualify for cash prizes and awards.  

The Pisgah Bike Omnium is a USA Cycling sanctioned event whereby all riders must hold or purchase a USA Cycling license to race. Cat 4 women and Cat 5 men may use a one-day USAC license. Entry fee includes USAC insurance surcharges. No license, no race, no exceptions. Entry fees include a $3.00 per rider USAC insurance fee and a $1.00 per rider CCA fee.  A $10 late fee for all on-site, day of registration. The Race Director has the right to combine races and can adjust prize lists due to registration numbers that do not meet the minimum field size requirements. Fields below minimum requirement will results in a payout of 50% of the listed payout. Races held rain or shine under USAC rules and permit. Entry fee is non-refundable.

title: Hot Doggett 100
description:
It is Spring in the Mountains of Western North Carolina! Our beautiful hills, forests and streams are coming back to life. Soon they will be lush and full of the sounds and smells of summer - and we hope full of cyclists riding the 8th Annual Hot Doggett - either on the Doggett Mountain Challenge (100 miles) or the Devils Fork Metric Challenge. The chatter has already started on facebook - tune in!

Early scouting of the course tells us the roads are in as good a shape as last year and in some places much improved. The Rotary Club of Madison County, which is the organizing group for the Hot Doggett series, has already assembled its team to make sure we bring you the same incredible experience as in prior years - in fact we strive every year to make sure the experience is better than the last. Last year we added some great sponsors that helped provide great swag - we welcome back many of them again this year (see our sponsors\' page). Their logos will be emblazoned on the 2nd annual souvenir rider jersey (cost $75 plus NC State sales tax).

We will again have discounts for early registration and prize drawings for early registrants. We will have the same opportunity for early packet pick-up (3 pm to 6 pm on Friday July 12), the same early morning camaraderie at the start-finish line, the same well-stocked rest stops and friendly volunteers, plenty of SAG support on the course, and the cold wet towels and the post ride meal at the finish - and the same tough climbs and screaming descents. Showers will again be available after the ride and Mars Hill College has dorm rooms available for $25/night for those who want to stay really close by.

We are very fortunate to be able to partner with Mars Hill College, which serves as host to all of our event preparations, our logistics and our start-finish operations - we do hope you will come out and ride our quiet mountain roads on July 13 and enjoy the beauty of the Mars Hill College Campus. If you are bringing friends or family, they can find all sorts of things to do in Madison County - just go to visitmadisoncounty.com to get some ideas.
Visit Madison County

We look forward to welcoming new and repeat riders alike.

Rick and Connie Molland,
2013 Event Chairs
course:
There are two courses: a 100 mile century ride or a 100 kilometer metric century.

1) Hot Doggett 100 Mile Century Ride
Saturday, July 13, 2013 - 7:30 AM Start-time

This challenging course leaves from Mars Hill and offers rolling hills for the first twenty miles, climbing a total of 2200 feet by mile 20. Then as you roll through the valley in Sandy mush you will see Doggett Mountain looming in front of you. With an average grade of 7% the base of the climb is the hardest, then after mile two the grade lessens and you get into a good rhythm to the top. At the top there will be plenty of food and drink to recover! Next is an awesome descent into Spring Creek with great roads all the way to Hot Springs. This is one of the fastest portions of the course, alongside Spring Creek. Once in Hot Springs check out the stores and the third rest stop close to the railroad tracks.

As you leave Hot Springs there is a three-mile climb that intersects the Appalachian Trail at the top, and offers a spectacular view in either direction. After the descent we go to Shelton Laurel (one of the most scenic parts of Madison County) with rolling hills to the base of Devils Fork. Then comes a two-mile climb, with one 1/8-mile section attaining a 15% grade! At the top we cross into Tennessee and descend to Flag Pond.

Once in Flag Pond, we get to climb Sams Gap back up to 4000 feet into North Carolina. After a screaming descent comes one last climb over Murray Mountain with another screaming descent bringing us back to Mars Hill. After 9600 feet of total elevation gain youll be happy to see the car. Showers will be available for men and women. 

2) Devil\'s Fork 100 Kilometer Metric Century Ride
Saturday, July 13, 2013 - 8:00 AM Start-time 



The 100K course begins on Highway 213 and turns onto Gabriel\'s Creek Road. The next 10K is a series of warm-up hills through the rolling country of southern Madison County. At Walnut Creek Road, we split from the 100M century and move directly towards the mountains that will be the challenge for the rest of the course.

The Walnut Creek Mountain ride starts at a moderate grade but turns steeper for a long climb. As we turn at the peak look to the right for a spectacular view of the Big Laurel Valley. Then a long decent leads to the first rest stop at the turn onto Big Laurel Road.

While in the Big Laurel community we pass through Revere and Spill Corn communities and rejoin the 100M Century. In historic Shelton Laurel we climb to the top of Devil\'s Fork, including an 1/8-mile section reaching 15% grade. At the top is the Appalachian Trail and a rest stop!

Descending into Tennessee, there are more great views. Once in Flag Pond you will be faced with a challenging five-mile climb up Sam\'s Gap to another rest stop. A screaming descent back into North Carolina awaits, with one last climb up Murray Mountain and another screaming descent to the finish line in Mars Hill. Once back, enjoy a post ride meal, hot showers and see if you won a door prize.
directions:
Start/Finish at Wren Student Union on the campus of Mars Hill College at 100 Athletic St, Mars Hill, NC 28754

http://www.mhc.edu/admissions/visit-us/directions-to-campus

title: Mars Hill Summer Cycling Camp
description: Building on the success of last years camp, we are once again ready to rip your legs off and elevate your game. Well train your brain toowith elite level tactics and race proven secrets to success. Come sharpen fitness and fine tune race strategy before you tackle the regions premier omnium: The French Broad Cycling Classic. This year the FBCC will be the final event of the CCAs Junior Development Series, as well as the third stop on the inaugural Southeast Regional Series, awarding all USAC junior categories. If theres one race in the SE that you must attend, this is it. And we will make sure youre better prepared than the competition. Visit our Facebook page (Mars Hill Cycling Camp) to learn more about last years camp and stay updated on this years developments.
course:
The camp will specifically focus on the time trial, climbing, and criterium skills/tactics youll need to have an awesome race. Well preview courses during the week and come up with a plan of attack. Pre-race strategy and tactics will be followed by post-race reviews of each race. A great opportunity to put into practice specific knowledge learned during the week and receive immediate feedback from coaches afterward.

New/improved courses this year: The time trial will start in downtown Marshall. The road race will also start in Marshall and finish just north of Mars Hill atop the California Creek Climb, which is about 3 miles long at 7%. The criterium will be at Biltmore Square Park. There will be categories for men and women in every junior age group: 10-12, 13-14, 15-16, and 17-18. Stay tuned to the race website: www.frenchbroadcyclingclassic.com. Get ready for some epic racing!
notes:
BENEFITS:
 Riding in the beautiful mountains.
 All meals and training fuel provided.
 PowerTap wheels to demo for all campers plus amazing pre-order deals on PowerTap wheels, Joule computers, CycleOps trainers, and Saris racks.
 Free official Mars Hill College team jersey (If registered by June 1)
 Ride as a team at French Broad Cycling Classic*
 Course previews for French Broad Cycling Classic
 Led by USAC certified coaches, national champions, and professionals.
* USA Cycling upgrade points are available for Cat 5 to 4 and Cat 4 to 3 upgrades based on Rule 1E2 (C).  Riders upgrading to Cat 4 will receive 2 race day credits for participating, while riders upgrading to Cat 3 will receive 3 upgrade points for completion of the camp.

*Teams formed based on registration in each age/category.

TOPICS COVERED:
 Race strategy and tactics for individuals and teams
 Skills and bike handling sessions
 Racing and training with a power meter
 Endurance training plans and goal setting
 Race preparation, fueling, and recovery
 Aerodynamics, power-to-weight, and equipment selection
 Mechanics workshop covering maintenance and basic repair
 Core strength, flexibility, and proper bike fit
 Climbing, descending, sprinting, cornering, time trialing, attacking, bridging

PRESENTATIONS and STAFF: A variety of elite coaches, pro riders, and industry experts will lend their expertise throughout camp.

Andy Applegate: A USAC Level 1 coach working with Carmichael Training Systems, Andy will give a presentation on racing strategy/tactics and how to get the most out of training and racing with a power meter. Plus, hes got the racing resume to back it up.

Lesli Meadows: A USAC Level 1 coach and owner of Asheville Fitness Club, Lesli will lead our skills and drills sessions. Lesli is a longtime coach, mentor, and all around supporter of junior cycling and has a masters degree in exercise physiology.

Jacob McGahey: The operations manager at Industry Nine Componentry will give a talk on equipment choices, aerodynamics, and power-to-weight. Jacob shares the secrets on how to get the most out of your fitness and tactics by choosing the right equipment for time trials, road races, and criteriums.

Sonni Dyer: The head coach at Studio7 MultiSport, Sonni will discuss optimal race-day fueling and recovery choices needed in both one and multiple day events. You know you need to eat and drink but when, what, and how much? Sonni will draw from his many years as an elite racer and coach.

Joey Coddington: Director of the Asheville Youth Cycling program, which has guided members to 12 national junior championship podiums and graduated riders to professional and national teams. Joey will talk about what it takes to develop up through the ranks of top level junior racing and on into the pros. Joey also works with the United Healthcare Pro Cycling Team.

Andy Crater: A longtime pro level racer with national titles and NRC wins under his belt, Andy is a Registered Yoga Teacher and Certified Teachers Assistant and will lead morning exercises focusing on flexibility, core strength, and breathing techniques.
directions:
LODGING and LOCATION: Air conditioned rooms in Brown Residence Hall: After a complete renovation in 2002, Brown Residence Hall has become one of the nicest living spaces on campus. Brown houses up to 60 people in mostly single rooms in suite style configurations. Each suite consists of two bedrooms and a private bath. Brown also has four mini-apartments for four residents, and is one of the few residence halls that has air conditioning in each room.

Directions: take exit 11 off I-26. Head up hill, go through light at Main St, then descend hill and turn left onto Dormitory Rd. Brown Hall is at the very top.

Mars Hill College
100 Athletic Street
Mars Hill,  NC 28754

title: Sizzler
description: 16th Annual Sizzler Cross country mountain bike race.   $1,000 Cash prize to Pro-Expert class. 100% payback to other experts. Prize awards are given 3 deep in each class.  Awards and prizes given out 1 hour after each race ending.
course: Using the famous Owl\'s Roost Trail, this even is mostly singletrack through the woods along the edge of Lake Brandt.
registration: Day of registration in the shelter #7 near the wildlife center and by the lake.  Registration starts at 8 am and closes 15 minutes prior to each race.
notes: All entry fees are non-refundable, but may be transferred with appropriate paperwork on race day.   Organizer reserves the right to combine classes when a specified field has less than 5 racers.  Cat1 racers require annual USA license.  All other racers may buy 1 day license at event for $5.   Approved Helmet required.

title: The Brenner Fit Challenge & Bike race
The Tobacco Road Classic
description:
Join the Wake Forest University Cycling Club for our first installment of an ACCC Mountain Bike Race. Registration goes from 7:30-8:30 am. 

Contact Wade Collins
Phone: 423.677.0679
Email: cycling@wfu.edu
course:
There will be three events: 

1. Short Track Cross Country
2. Individual Time Trial
3. Downhill/Super-D

Short Track: The course starts with a brief uphill field start, then travels counter-clockwise into the woods. The first half of the woods has smooth, flowy singletrack before finishing the loop with a technical rock garden descent. 

TT: The uphill time trial will begin shortly after the completion of the Men's A ST race and involve 500 feet of vertical climbing over a 2 mile course. The first rider goes off at 12:30, starting with Men's C. Riders will follow at 30 second intervals.

Super-D/DH: The Super-D/DH course will be an individual time trial involving some flowy berms with a barrage of rock gardens and other natural technical features. The first rider goes off at 2:00, starting with Men's C. Riders will follow at 30 second intervals.
registration:
Please pre-register at acccyling.org/registration/ 

Open til 9/7/2013 10:00 pm
directions:
Address: Moore's Springs Campground, Danbury, NC

GPS Coordinates: 36.420039, -80.284359

Directions from Winston-Salem/Wake Forest Univeristy: http://goo.gl/maps/whuq6

title: Wilkesboro Cyclocross Festival - SECX #3 & #4 & NCCX #8
description:
The Fourth Annual Wilkesboro Cyclocross Festival returns the weekend before Thanksgiving for two days of incredible racing! The races are also the second stop in the Southeast Cyclocross Super Series, along with the Savannah Superprestige, Charleston CX Doublehead, and the Kingsport (TN) Cup! Check out www.SECyclocross.com for more info.

This year, we are introducing a flatter Speed Course for Saturday, to balance out the racing, and save your legs for the roller coaster ride of the Sundays Technical Course which made Cyclocross Magazines call it a Race You Do Not Want to Miss and one of the Best New Races of 2012.

Keep an eye on the High Country Cyclocross Facebook Page for updates on the race, and some exciting announcements, and make your reservations to stay in Wilkesboro!
course:
Saturday: Speed Course

We are flattening out the race for Day One to mix it up a little, and save your legs for the second day of racing
http://ridewithgps.com/routes/3101510

Sunday: Technical Course

The same challenging course from 2012 that earned the Wilkesboro Cyclocross Fesitval a nomination from Cyclocross Magazines for Best New Race
http://ridewithgps.com/routes/851975
registration:
Sign up for both events on Pre-Reg.com. Sunday is listed under "2013 NCCX Series." Registration is $20 online, $30 at the event, except for elite men and women $25/$35. Second race same day only $10.

Collegiate registration and check-in will open at 7:15 am on Saturday. Collegiate racers should pre-register at acccycling.org. 
Collegiate racers may register for a second non-collegiate race Saturday on site for $10.
notes: The Wilkesboro Cyclocross Festival is race #3 and #4 in the Southeast Cyclocross Super Series (http://www.secyclocross.com). Sunday races are also part of the North Carolina Cyclocross Series (http://www.nccyclocross.com).
directions:
Google/GPS to Snyder St, Wilkesboro, NC 28697

Go to http://highcountrycx.com/directions for maps and detailed instructions.

From US-421 N take Exit 268A  NC 16/NC 18 exit.
Turn Left at end of ramp
Follow NC-16/NC-18 1 mile through Downtown Wilkesboro.
Go Straight onto Old US-421 at light past Re-Store, at intersection with Oakwoods Rd (do not follow NC-16/NC-18).
Follow Old US-421 about 1/2 mile to a bridge crossing
Take Left after crossing bridge onto Snyder St into Wilkesboro Wastewater Treatment Plant
Go straight up hill through white gate, past brick building on left.
Turn Right on Toms Roost, up steep gravel road.
You may park in field adjacent to bath house on left
OR continue up hill (steep gravel, be cautious of water bars) and park adjacent to registration and the finish at the top of the hill.
OR go straight past Toms Roost
Turn Right past buildings
Follow gravel road up hill to clearing on left, registration is on the right (this is further from the bathrooms, but close to registration)
